page.title: 02LANDSCAPE
page.content: The surrounding countryside is rich and varied.The farms to the east and north lie on the western edge of the Carse of Stirling which encompasses some of the finest arable farmlands in Scotland.To the south,spreading down from the Campsies into the valley are hill farms,where the emphasis is on stock farming. The Stirling family,which tended the Garden estate for centuries,were tree planters,hence the landscape is dominated by venerable oaks,chestnuts,beeches,sycamores and elders,which grow on the margins of the fields and by the roadsides, and by the small clumps of pine woods planted in more recent times.The fields generally are surrounded by stout hedges of thorn,beech and holly and the overall impression is both rich and colourful.
